intro: Gymnanthemum quercifolium, commonly known as the oak-leaved false holly, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its opposite, ovate leaves that resemble those of oak trees. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters, which are typically borne in the axils of the leaves. Its fruit is a small, dry capsule that contains several seeds. Gymnanthemum quercifolium is often found in moist, shaded habitats such as woodlands and along stream banks.
